316. Fish, (Mrs. John)
Plato Homemaker Club

WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. John Fish
Address Plato, Sask.
Birthplace Denmark but grown up in Iowa, U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1912
Where did you set up housekeeping? Aurora, Homestead, 14-36-18-153rd
Where had you been living before that? Shelby County, Iowa, U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Eight
How far was it to your nearest store? 26 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? about once a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, some dried fruit, cereals, lard, some canned milk, potatoes and beans.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Fischer and Fine Ross
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.25
How much did you use graham flour? Not much
Whole wheat flour? Not much
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? ...... What year? ......
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...........
What other grain products did you use? ........................................
Cornmeal? Yes Whole wheat? Farina? Other? ........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? .................................................................
Platt Hour Maker Club

Questionnaire: P.113 In a month of data concerning the use of our club and will it be satisfactory to Mrs. John Fish, (Mrs. John Fish)

Name: Mrs. John Fish
Address: Platt, New Hampshire
Birthplace: Danvers, Massachusetts, USA

1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS:
   - What year did you start homemaking? (1912)
   - Where did you meet your husband? (Boston, Massachusetts)
   - How far was it to your nearest store? (2 miles)
   - How often could a visit be made to the store? (Every week or two months)
   - What materials did you usually buy in those distant years? (Flour, sugar, tea, etc.)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER FOODS:
   - Have you used any flour in the last year? (Yes)
   - To what quantity did you use it? (100 lbs.)
   - How much did you use? (25 lbs.)
   - What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? ($2.50)
   - What other flour products did you use? (Cornmeal)
   - Did you grind your own wheat for bread? (No)
   - How did you grind it? (Hand mill)
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 65¢.
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers & Sons.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 oz.
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We did not get any. The first year we were there.
Butter? At the store.
Eggs? At store if they had them.
What was the price of butter? 20¢ a lb.
Of eggs?
Did you pick eggs for winter? Not very many.
Did you make butter? Not until 1916.
Cheese? Not.
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Bacon and salt pork and some beef when we could get it.
How did you get fresh meat? From town. Buy from some home steaders that raised them.
How often did you get fresh meat? Not after the first year.
How did you preserve meat? After we had our own flock we pickled it in a brine or fried it down.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Not much. What kinds?
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? Very small part.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?
Kinds?

In what quantity did you buy this last summer? 2.0 lbs. Sugar

What was the price? For a ten pound sack of white sugar? $6.30

That brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Remedy I

That size of tin of grape did you usually buy? 10 oz. 20 cents

At what prices?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We did not get any.

Did you have cows? Yes

What was the price of butter? 20¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for market? No

Did you make butter? Not until 1916

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND GAME

What was your meat supply in the early years? Before and after

How did you get fresh meat? From the woods and farms

How often did you get fresh meat? Not often

How did you preserve meat? Often we had our own and would freeze it

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Not much

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very small part

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?

Kind?

What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea in bulk
What price?
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Chase & Sanborn
Price?

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? Sometimes
If not, where from?
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1913 Cabbage 1813 Carrots 1913 Onions Not many
Turnips 1913 Beets 1913
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 5 lbs
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box
What weight? 5 lbs
How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes
What was the price of prunes?
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?
Raisins, Apples and Peaches

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No
peas? No corn? No beans? No Saskatoons? No
other foods?
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1915
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1925
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1930
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes
Canning of fruit and vegetables
To what extent?
Did you make your own vinegar? Yes at times

Did you make yeast for your own use? No

Had most all these articles in the store when we came in 1912.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) through the first 3 months, then dug a well.

How far was this water from your home? Just a few rods.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) By barrel or stone boat.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Near our part of the Country most everyone had a well and the water was good. But South west of Plato it was almost impossible to get water so dug outs were used and some hauled water from a spring.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? We done both.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... wood ashes? No.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal, wood, some charcoal.

Where did you get your fuel? At Brook and some wood from the Saskatchewan River.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wood and Coal were our fuels until the last five years we have used fuel oil for heating.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ..............................................................

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ..............................................................

By whom was your first cook stove made? We bought it from the States.

What year was it purchased? 1909. Price? ...................................................

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and copper.

For preparing food? (chips, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) mostly Enamel ware, some Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Several years after we came here.

Aluminum? Several years after we came here.
